Graphical abstract Incorporating of the partially-fluorinated co-solvent ETFB fine-tunes the electrolyte’s solvation structure, resulting in wide-temperature and flame-retardancy properties. This promotes the formation of LiF-rich SEI/CEI and the performance improvement of 4.5 V Li||LCO cells within wide-temperature ranges. Efficient, safe, and reliable energy output from high-energy–density lithium metal batteries (LMBs) at all climates is crucial for portable electronic devices operating in complex environments. The performance of corresponding cathodes and lithium (Li) metal anodes, however, faces significant challenges under such demanding conditions. Herein, a nonflammable electrolyte for high-voltage Li||LCO cells has been designed, including partially-fluorinated ethyl 4,4,4-trifluorobutyrate (ETFB) as the key solvent, guided by theoretical calculations. With this ETFB-based electrolyte, Li||LCO cells exhibit enhanced reversible capacities and superior capacity retention at an elevated charge voltage of 4.5 V and a wide operating temperature range spanning from −60 °C to 70 °C. The cells achieve 67.1% discharge capacity at −60 °C, relative to room temperature capacity, and 85.9% 100th-cycle retention at 70 °C. The outstanding properties are attributed to the LiF-rich interphases formed in the ETFB-based electrolyte with a fine-tuned solvation structure, in which the coordination environment in the vicinity of Li+ cations and the distance between anion and solvents are subtly adjusted by introducing ETFB. This solvation structure has been mutually elucidated through joint spectra characterizations and atomistic simulations. This work presents a new strategy for the design of electrolytes to achieve all-climate reliable and safe application of LMBs. Keywords Lithium metal battery Partially-fluorinated electrolyte High-voltage LiCoO2 Wide-temperature battery 1 Introduction Recently, secondary lithium metal batteries (LMBs) have become a hotspot again on account of the continuous pursuit of high-energy–density batteries. Similar to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) for consumer electronics and electric vehicles, it is crucial for high-energy–density LMBs to possess the characteristics of wide-temperature operation to meet the increasing performance requirements [1]. However, stability issues with LMBs, especially Li dendrites developed from uneven Li deposition, limit their practical application [2]. The continuous and complex side reactions between Li metal anodes (LMAs) and electrolytes cause the loss of Li metal and electrolyte, decreasing the Coulombic efficiency (CE) and cycle life of LMBs [2,3]. In particular, with traditional carbonate electrolytes, severe growth of Li dendrites accompanying large volume expansion after extended cycles, especially at low temperatures (< −20 °C), continues to pose significant safety concerns [4,5]. On the cathode side, typical materials with high specific capacity, such as LiCoO2 (LCO) [6], LiNixCoyMnzO2 (NCM) [7,8], xLiMO2·(1-x)Li2MnO3 (LLOs) [9] and LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 [10] exhibit unstable electrochemical properties that limit further development of high-energy-dense LMBs, due to electrolyte decomposition and unstable cathode/electrolyte interface (CEI) formed at high voltages (> 4.4 V) [11,12]. Specifically, when the LCO cathode is charged at a cut-off voltage of 4.2 V, the actual reversible capacity (∼140 mAh·g−1) represents only about half of its theoretical capacity (275 mAh·g−1) [13,14]. Although higher charge cut-off voltages can improve the specific capacity of LCO, the unstable CEI formed can induce oxygen evolution and bulk phase deformations, especially under high temperatures (> 50 °C), aggravating the deterioration of electrochemical properties. Hence, to achieve high-energy–density LMBs for all climate, even at ultralow to ultrahigh temperatures (i.e., wide-temperature range), the ideal LMBs electrolyte should be designed for establishing stable electrode interfaces on both cathode and anode. In this context, various strategies regarding electrolyte design have been developed by controlling solvation structure [15–18] and interfacial chemistry [19,20], including novel salt or solvent additives [8,9,21–27], high concentration electrolytes (HCEs) [28], local high concentration electrolytes (LHCEs) [10,29–31] and competition coordination strategies [17,32–34]. Low-temperature electrolyte designs often incorporate carboxylate ester solvents, with lower viscosity and melting points than carbonate solvents, in normal concentration electrolytes (∼1 M) [24,35–37] to ensure proper conductivity at low temperatures. However, this approach overlooks the negative impact of poor oxidation resistance of free ester solvents at high potentials. On the other hand, strategies involving electrolytes with medium or high concentration aim to reducing the number of free carbonates in the solvation structure for better compatibility with the Li anode. Nevertheless, increasing concentration faces a challenge of decreased electrolyte conductivity [38–41]. To address this issue, fluorine-containing ethers or esters that do not dissolve lithium salts, such as 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl 2,2,2-trifluoroethyl ether [42,43], 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl-2,2,3,3-tetrafluoropropyl ether (TTE) [44–46] and ethyl heptafluorobutyrate (EHFB) [47], have been frequently used as highly efficient diluents for wide or ultralow temperature LHCEs electrolytes. In particular, partially fluoro-substitution carboxylic or carbonate ester (PFCE) gradually attract researchers’ attention. In addition to the excessively studied fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC), a series of PFCEs have been reported as effective cosolvents for wide or low-temperature electrolytes, including methyl (2,2,2-trifluoroethyl) carbonate (FEMC) [48,49], methyl 3,3,3-trifluoropionate (MTFP) [50], ethyl difluoroacetate (EFA) [51,52], and ethyl (2,2,2-trifluoroethyl) carbonate (ETFEC) [53]. These LFCEs exhibit excellent antioxidant properties induced by fluorine-groups while maintaining solubility for lithium salts with proper conductivity, and low viscosity. Besides, most of them are beneficial for formatting of LiF-rich SEI films on account of low LUMO levels [54,55]. Among these fluorinated solvents, ethyl 4,4,4-trifluorobutyrate (ETFB) has been reported in a few reports, and holds a great potential for Li+ de/solvation in LMBs due to its particularly levels of fluorination [25,47]. The 1% ETFB additive has been reported to improve electrochemical properties of Ni-rich cathode under high voltage (4.4 V) [25]. Inspired by the above research, it is necessary to further study the Li+ solvation behavior in ETFB, to understand its influence on electrochemical properties, and to clarify its application in high voltage LCO||Li battery system (≥ 4.5 V). In this work, a fluorinated electrolyte (1 M LiPF6 in an optimized FEC:ETFB = 1:4 (v/v), with a molar ratio of FEC:ETFB ≈ 1:2, by comparing different FEC:ETFB ratios as shown in Fig. S1) was prepared, in which partially-fluorinated solvent ETFB was the main solvent with weakly solvating FEC, to explore fluorine substitution effect of electrolyte on the interfacial solvation structure. For comparison, 1 M LiPF6 in FEC:EB = 1:4 (v/v) (FEC/EB), 1 M LiPF6 in EC:EB = 1:4 (v/v) (EC/EB) and conventional carbonate-based electrolyte 1 M LiPF6 in EC:DEC = 1:1 (v/v) (EC/DEC) were also prepared. Atomic and molecular simulation, and spectroscopy analysis demonstrate that the introduction of ETFB optimizes the interaction of Li+-anion ion-pair and achieves excellent physical and chemical properties (non-flammability, high voltage resistance and favorable electrical conductivity), thus forming a stable LiF-rich interface layer (SEI and CEI) and facilitating the transport of Li+ during the cycle. As a result, the capacity retention rate of the Li||LCO cell (3–4.5 V) after 200 cycles at 25 °C is 91.9%, while that after 100 cycles at −40 °C and 70 °C are 67.1% and 85.9%, respectively. In addition, the Li||LCO pouch cell was also verified to implement wide temperature characteristic. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Design and features of the ETFB-based electrolyte The molecular structure of the selected solvents in this work is depicted in Fig. 1 a. Among them, ethylenecarbonate (EC) and diethylcarbonate (DEC) are commonly utilized as the primary solvent in the presently commercialized LIBs electrolytes owing to their cost-efficiency and exceptional electrochemical stability. Carboxylate ester ethyl butyrate (EB), a structural analogue of DEC, has also been verified as an co-solvent for effectively broaden the low-temperature electrochemical performance of the LIBs [56]. Furthermore, The fluorinated carboxylate ETFB containing a –CF3 functional group, alongside FEC as a co-solvent, was used as solvent for a F-ester based electrolyte. The selection of this fluorocarboxylate ester as the main solvent of LMBs electrolyte offers following advantages. (i) The substitution of fluorine-containing groups in both solvents of FEC/ETFB electrolyte, for the solvent components exhibited lower HOMO energy levels and lower LUMO energy levels compared to those of the solvents in both the base electrolytes (EC/DEC) and other electrolytes (EC/EB, FEC/EB), owing to the elevated electronegativity, high ionic potential, and low polarizability of the F atom [43,50]. The HOMO energy levels decrease in the order of EB (−7.65 eV) < DEC (−8.05 eV) < ETFB (−8.14 eV) < EC (−8.47 eV) < FEC (−8.97 eV), as illustrated in Fig. 1b, indicating an enhanced resistance to oxidation against high voltage cathodes for ETFB-based electrolyte. Moreover, the subsequent linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) tests (Fig. S2a) confirmed a further enhancement in decomposition voltage of the FEC/ETFB electrolyte, reaching up to 4.9 V, surpassing that of the compared electrolyte (FEC/ETFB > FEC/EB > EC/DEC > EC/EB). Compared with the solvents in the baseline electrolyte, both FEC and ETFB exhibit a higher abundance of F-containing groups and possess lower LUMO energy levels (Fig. 1b) than F-free carbonate or ester, implying that they have the potential to form a LiF-rich solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) on Li-metal surfaces. (ii) Compared with EC and EB solvents, F-substitutions in FEC and ETFB decrease the charge density on the O atoms of the C=O carbonyl group (Fig. 1b). This charge distribution change results in their lower interaction with Li+ cation and PF6 − anion, as depicted by the binding energy of solvent molecules with Li+ ions and PF6 − anions calculated using DFT (Fig. 1c). The weaker binding energies (ΔE Li-S) between Li+ and FEC (ΔE Li-FEC = 1.67 eV) as well as ETFB (ΔE Li-ETFB = 1.54 eV), which are lower than Li+-EC (ΔE Li-EC = 1.92 eV) and Li+-EB (ΔE Li-EB = 1.85 eV), respectively, can facilitate the Li+ desolvation in the electrolyte during electrochemical processes, thereby enhancing kinetic performance of the cell, particularly at low temperatures. (iii) The ionic conductivity of FEC/ETFB electrolyte, as shown in Fig. 1d, demonstrates relatively favorable values within the temperature range of −60 °C to 70 °C (Fig. 1d). Although the FEC/ETFB electrolyte exhibits slightly lower ionic conductivity (3.76 mS·cm−1) than the traditional EC/DEC electrolyte (6.87 mS·cm−1) at room temperature (RT, 25 °C), its conductivity outperforms that of EC/DEC electrolyte at temperature lower than −20 °C. The abrupt decrease in the ionic conductivity of EC/DEC electrolyte at approximately −20 °C is attributed to the solidification phenomenon occurring within the electrolyte due to the high melting point of EC, as proved by DSC test (Fig. S2b) [44]. The DSC test (Fig. S2b) demonstrates that the FEC/ETFB electrolyte exhibits a lower melting point (∼ −73 °C), ensuring its non-solidification even at low temperatures of −60 °C (Fig. 1d). (iv) The introduction of –F group also enables FEC/ETFB excellent wettability and good flame retardant characteristics. The exceptional wettability of the FEC/ETFB electrolyte is demonstrated by the contact angle test, as shown in Fig. S2c, conducted on the surface of the Celgard separator. In Fig. 1e and Fig. S3 of self-extinguishing test (SET), 0.2 mL FEC/ETFB electrolyte shows no ignite even after three times of butane spray gun flame contact, while for other electrolytes, including the baseline electrolyte, all have burning phenomena of various temporal durations (SETEC/DEC > SETEC/EB > SETFEC/EB), indicating that FEC/ETFB electrolyte had nonflammable feature. Aforementioned advantages collectively imply the substantial potential of its application in driving all-climate, high-safety LMBs systems. 2.2 Molecular dynamic simulation and characterization for solvation structure of electrolytes Detailed dynamic solvation structure of the electrolytes were simulated by molecular dynamics (MD) simulation because this method plays an indispensable role in elucidating the solvation structure of the electrolyte, unraveling the ion transport mechanism, and deciphering the interphase formation mechanism at the electrolyte–electrode interface [57]. Fig. 2 a, b and Fig. S4 show the radial distribution functions (RDFs) and the coordination numbers (CN) of solvent molecules/anions with respect to Li+ in the FEC/EB, FEC/ETFB, EC/DEC and EC/EB electrolytes, respectively. The CN of FEC in the FEC/EB and FEC/ETFB electrolytes are significantly lower (0.53 and 0.61) than these of EC in EC/EB and EC/DEC (1.44 and 2.93), indicating a much lower Li+ coordination ability for FEC compared with EC. Furthermore, the CN of ETFB (2.98) in FEC/ETFB electrolyte is similar to that of EB in FEC/EB (2.96), both slightly higher than that of EB in EC/EB (2.58), suggesting an improved Li+ coordination ability for ETFB and EB when combined with FEC, relative to EB combined with EC. Considering the HOMO levels of the solvent molecules (Fig. 1b), ETFB proves to have more reduction tendency than EB, making it a better solvent in the primary solvation sheath in terms of forming LiF-rich SEI films on LMAs. For the similar reason, the number of anions in the primary solvation sheath is also of importance, which is greatly affected by interactions between anions and solvent molecules. At the truncation radius of 2.8 Å, CNs of Li-F (for accessing the coordination with PF6 −) in the FEC/ETFB, FEC/EB, EC/EB and EC/DEC electrolyte systems are 1.76, 1.86, 1.51 and 0.71, respectively, suggesting the weak coordination nature of solvents in FEC/ETFB and FEC/EB systems, which increases the CN of PF6 − relative to that in the carbonate solvent system. Similar trends of the favorable participation of the fluorinated ester solvent in the solvation structure have also been observed in Raman spectrum (Fig. 2c). The characteristic Raman peak of the PF6 − anion locates at ∼740 cm−1. It should be pointed out that the solvated and free PF6 − Raman signals cannot be separated at the current Raman conditions, and similar result has been reported by previous papers [33,38,51]. Among the three Raman peaks of FEC in the range of 700–950 cm−1, the two at 868 cm−1 and 907 cm−1 overlap with those of ETFB and EB; therefore, we use the peak at ∼729 cm−1 to quantitatively identify the free FEC molecule (F-FEC) in electrolytes. For the two FEC-based electrolytes, because the concentrations of LiPF6 are the same, the corresponding area ratio of I F-FEC/I PF6 reflects the variation trend of free FEC molecules related to the total amount of PF6 − anions. I F-FEC/I PF6 value of FEC/ETFB electrolyte (0.59) is lower than that of FEC/EB electrolyte (0.70), suggesting that FEC solvent exists more in the coordination form than the free form in FEC/ETFB. The DFT calculation (Fig. 1c) shows that the Li+-solvation binding energies are in the order of ΔE Li-ETFB < ΔE Li-FEC < ΔE Li-EB, indicating a higher likelihood of Li+-FEC coordination in the FEC/ETFB electrolyte. This makes more FEC enter into the primary solvation sheath to facilitate the formation of an infinitesimal-rich SEI/CEI film. As shown in Fig. 2i, compared with EC-based electrolytes, in FEC/ETFB and FEC/EB electrolytes, solvation structures exhibit as contact ion pairs (CIPs) and higher ordered agglomerates (AGGs) in a higher abundance, similar to the results previously reported regarding the solvation structure of MCE or LHCE systems [15,29,31,38]. Typically, electrolyte box and CIPs for FEC/ETFB electrolytes obtained by MD is shown in Fig. 2j and 2 k, respectively.These solvation structures are different from those in the EC-based electrolytes, in which the PF6 − anions predominantly exist as free ions and solvent-shared ion pairs (SSIPs) within solvent structure (Fig. 2i) [38,50,58]. This solvation difference exhibits highly desirable characteristics, including the formation of CEI/SEI at the electrode/electrolyte interface and enhanced electrochemical stability at room or low temperature [10,28,38]. To further explore the detailed influence of ETFB on the solvation structure (specifically, the average distance between PF6 − and Li+), the coordination condition of PF6 − at different RDF is listed in Table S1. At a cut-off radius of 4.4 Å, the CNs of PF6 − in the FEC/ETFB and FEC/EB electrolytes remain elevated at levels of 5.82 and 5.89, respectively, surpassing those in EC-based electrolytes (2.45 for EC/DEC and 4.83 for EC/EB). This result confirms that PF6 − is compact from the Li+ core in the solvation structure of EC-based electrolyte, compared with the loose structure in FEC/linear carbonyl ester, and furthermore, PF6 − anions likely to appears slightly farther in the Li+ solvation sheath in the FEC/ETFB than in the FEC/EB. Moreover, the incorporation of the –CF3 group is speculated to introduce distinctive steric hindrance characteristics for PF6 −, thereby resulting in significant implications on anion distribution and the average length of Li-PF6 ion pairs within the solvation sheath. Fig. 2d and Fig. 2e show that RDF for ETFB and EB centered on PF6 − anions. Three carbon atoms, i.e., C1: terminal carbon of butyrate, C2: carbonyl carbon, C3: terminal carbon of ethyl, in ETFB and EB molecule structures were chosen to simulate and compare the change of distance between these carbon atoms in ETFB or EB and the core phosphorus atom in PF6 −, and then investigate the effects of fluorine-substitution on solvation structure. When the –CH3 group in EB is replaced by –CF3 group in ETFB, the RDF of P-C changes significantly, the peak position of g(r)max for dP-C1 shifts from 4.67 Å to 5.68 Å, dP-C2 from 5.07 Å to 5.15 Å and dP-C3 from 4.82 Å to 4.63 Å, respectively. Particularly, the ion–molecule interactions of Li+PF6 − ion pairs with EB (or ETFB) were also identified by the 1H-, 19F- and 7Li NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 2f–h and Fig. S5). In pure solvents (Fig. 2f), the 1H NMR chemical shifts for ETFB are at down field than the corresponding chemical shifts in EB, due to the presence of the –CF3 group. In electrolytes, solvation of both solvent molecules (EB and ETFB) leads to downfield shift of 1H NMR. The chemical shift of 1H NMR for –CH3 (C3) of ETFB solvents shows a smaller downfield value (∼0.04 ppm) than EB solvents (∼0.08 ppm) after solvation. In FEC/ETFB, the chemical shift of 19F NMR for –CF3 in ETFB has an obviously downfield shifts of 0.32 ppm. Meanwhile, the chemical shift of 1H NMR on –CH3 (C1) of FEC/EB undergoes a smaller downfield shift of 0.06 ppm than that on –CH3(C3), verifying that –CF3 group on FEC/ETFB have a different effect on the Li-PF6 ion pairs compared to FEC/EB. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 2g and 2 h, chemical shifts of both 19F NMR (PF6 −) and 7Li NMR of FEC/ETFB are in upfield related those of FEC/EB, suggesting that shielding effect from PF6 −-solvent interaction of FEC/ETFB outweighs FEC/EB. As shown in Fig. 2i, although the total proportion of the CIPs and AGGs solvation types for FEC/ETFB and FEC/EB is close (74.9% and 70.6%, respectively), the CIPs proportion in FEC/ETFB system is much higher, reaching 64.6%, related to 38.2% in FEC/EB system. During Li+ de/solvation process, solvation structure of FEC/ETFB dominated by CIPs and AGGs is more beneficial to the formation of rich LiF interface layers and lowers Li+ de/solvation energy, compared with the SSIPs-rich structure [59–61]. The solvated CIPs structure has higher thermodynamic stability than the AGG structure when the ambient temperature from RT changes to low temperature [62]. These differences suggest that by precisely modifying the solvent molecules, the fine-tuning of solvation structure can be achieved. Overall, based on the above simulation and characterization, the characteristic solvation structure of the electrolytes can be depicted in Fig. 2l. The mild repulsive effect between –CF3 and PF6 − (solvent-anion interaction) weakens the deshielding effect of Li+ and diminishes the electrostatic interaction between Li+ and PF6 − (i.e., the distance is farther in the order of d FEC/EB < d FEC/ETFB ≪ d EC/DEC), thereby favorably positioning the PF6 − anion within the solvation sheath, thus facilitating efficient desolation capability of the electrolyte for easier de/solvation of Li+ ions from the solvation sheath. The aforementioned variation serves as a further demonstration of the existence and significant impact of solvent-anion interactions. While this ETFB co-solvation structure is commonly associated with highly desirable properties, such as non-flammability, high voltage stability, and good electrical conductivity, the influence of this structure on the CEI/SEI film-forming ability and its electrochemical properties at wide temperature needs further investigation. 2.3 Reversibility of lithium anodes in the electrolytes The Coulombic efficiency (CE) of the Li||Cu cell was directly tested using the above electrolytes at a current density of 0.5 mA·cm−2 to investigate the reversibility of Li plating/stripping, as depicted in Fig. 3 a and Fig. S6. The Li||Cu cell with FEC/ETFB electrolyte achieved an initially Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 93.1%, significantly higher than those for Li||Cu cells employing EC/DEC and FEC/EB electrolytes (87.0% and 92.3%, respectively). Evidently, upon implementation of the FEC/ETFB electrolyte, the CE of cell exhibits a rapid increase to 97.2% after only 10 cycles and subsequently maintained stability at approximately 98.9% even after 300 cycles. Conversely, the cell employing the EC/DEC electrolyte experienced fluctuating CEs down to 84.2% during the first 70 cycles before plummeting to 58.7% in subsequent 30 cycles. Similar behavior was observed for cell with FEC/EB electrolyte around 100th cycle. The cell with EC/EB electrolyte exhibited a poor initial charge efficiency (ICE) of 69%. Subsequently, the reversible performance of EC/EB is deemed entirely unsatisfactory as it exhibited a sharp decline to nearly 0 after only 25 cycles (Fig. S6a). These apparent attenuations can be attributed to short circuits induced by severe Li dendrite growth. Long-term cycling stability analysis reveals that Li||Cu cells utilizing FEC/ETFB electrolyte effectively exhibit superior reversibility probably due to the inhibition of Li dendrite growth. The plating/stripping curves of Li||Cu cell with FEC/ETFB and other electrolytes are shown in Fig. 3b and Fig. S6b, c respectively. The electroplating curve for FEC/ETFB electrolyte shows a significant decrease in voltage difference (ΔV) during cycles, and the ΔV of plating/stripping curves decreases from 64 mV at 3rd cycle to 52 mV at 30th cycle and then remains stable in the subsequent cycle, indicating that the cycling kinetics was excellent. However, other electrolytes (Fig. S6) all show an increasing ΔV, which is much larger than the ΔV of FEC/ETFB electrolyte at the corresponding cycles, indicating degradation in different degrees of plating/stripping kinetics. Li||Li symmetrical cell were investigating the reversibility of Li plating/stripping simultaneously. Fig. 3c and Fig. S6e demonstrate the rate performance of Li||Li symmetric cells with different electrolytes under increasing current densities (10 cycles per current density, with each charge/discharge lasting for 2 h). When the current density ranges from 0.5 to 5 mA·cm−2, the overpotential of the Li||Li symmetric cell with FEC/ETFB electrolyte is comparatively lower than those of other electrolytes. Moreover, it is noteworthy that the Li||Li cell employing FEC/ETFB electrolyte exhibits satisfactory performance even at a high current density of 5 mA·cm−2, whereas those using FEC/EB and EC/DEC electrolytes fail at currents of 3 mA·cm−2 and 4 mA·cm−2 respectively. The long-term cycling stability of the Li||Li cells was tested with different electrolytes under 1 mA·cm−2 (discharge 1 h and charge 1 h in each cycle) as shown in Fig. 3d and Fig. S6f. The FEC/ETFB electrolyte-based cell exhibits stable cycling performance for up to 800 h, whereas the other electrolyte-based cells fail no more than 360 h (EC/DEC > FEC/EB > EC/EB) due to short circuit caused by growth of Li dendrites. Since both solvent components in the FEC/ETFB electrolyte exhibit a greater tendency towards reduction on the Li anode [25,63], as confirmed by the DFT calculation results of HOMO levels (Fig. 1b) and the higher abundance of PF6 − anion coordination (Fig. 2c and Table S1), suggesting it can easily form LiF-rich SEI layer on the surface of the Li metal anode. LiF has considered to be a crucial decomposition product of the F-containing electrolyte and contributes to strengthened low temperature performance and cycle life of LMB and LIBs [12,63–66]. The Tafel curve slope of FEC/ETFB electrolyte (1.14 mA·cm−2) is lower than those of FEC/EB (1.33 mA·cm−2) and EC/DEC (1.72 mA·cm−2)(Fig. 3e). After different cycles, the resistance of the Li||Li cells determined by EIS tests. As shown in Fig. 3f, the cells employing FEC/ETFB electrolytes have smaller resistance than cells employing other electrolytes. Additionally, the cell with FEC/ETFB also exhibits more stable cycling (200 h) and less polarization than other electrolytes at low temperatures (−20 °C)(Fig. S7b). Even at temperatures of −40 °C and 60 °C, it also achieves stable cyclings (100 h)(Fig. S7a and Fig. S7c). All the above electrochemical analyses indicate that the FEC/ETFB electrolyte improves the electrochemical kinetics of Li||Li cells, resulting in a more stable cycle life and rate property. 2.4 Electrochemical performance of 4.5 V Li||LCO cells Given the fact that Li metal electrodes show entirely different electrochemical property in ETFB-based and other electrolytes, we tested the rate capability of Li||LCO cells using various electrolytes at RT within the voltage range of 3.0–4.5 V under different current densities (0.1 C–10 C, 1 C = 190 mA·g−1, with a LCO cathode loading of ∼9.5 mg·cm−2), as shown in Fig. 4 a and Fig. S8, to further evaluate electrochemical stability of electrolyte with cathodes. The corresponding capacity-voltage curves for Fig. 4a are shown in Fig. S9. The cells with FEC/ETFB electrolyte show the best rate capacities of 186, 183, 176, 169, 159, 146, and 127 mAh⋅g−1 at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, and 10 C. The rate performance of Li||LCO cells with different electrolytes ranks in the order of FEC/ETFB > EC/DEC > FEC/EB > EC/EB, remarkably consistent with the rate characteristics of Li||Li cells (Fig. 3c), suggesting that the electrochemical effect of electrolyte on Li metal can also extend to the Li||LCO cells. Fig. 4b shows the cycling performance of Li||LCO cells using different electrolytes at RT. In the EC/EB electrolyte, the cell displays a slump capacity fading only dozens of cycles, which results from the poor Li metal stability of the electrolyte. As for EC/DEC and FEC/EB electrolytes, the cells both exhibit unremarkable ICE (85% and 88%) and 1st reversible capacity (172 and 169 mAh·g−1). The continuous capacities fading was discovered in cells along with charge–discharge cycling. After 200 cycles, the cells retain reversible capacities of 92 and 121 mAh·g−1 (53.4% and 71.6% capacity retention) for EC/DEC and FEC/EB electrolytes, respectively. Compared with the former electrolytes, the cell with FEC/ETFB electrolyte exhibits excellent ICE (94.6%) and 1st reversible capacity (184 mAh·g−1). In addition, cycling stability of Li||LCO cells in FEC/ETFB electrolyte is also significantly improved, with the cells retaining 91.9% capacity after 200 cycles (Fig. 4b and Fig. S10). Furthermore, the dQ/dV and top views of its waterfall plots exhibited consistent redox peak positions of LCO from 6th to 200th cycles (first 5cycles for activation) with negligible peak shifts in the Fig. 4c and Fig. 4d. In contrast, oxidation peak positions of cells in FEC/EB and EC/DEC shift by 23 mV and 45 mV respectively, accompanied by a noticeable decrease in peak intensity (Fig. S11). Long cycle performance profiles of Li||LCO cells at different electrolytes are shown in Fig. 4g and Fig. S12. The cells match with FEC/ETFB exhibits most perdurable cycling abilities at 1 C, holding a steady capacity of 153 mAh⋅g−1 (89.4% of excellent retention refer to 6th cycle). The 300-cycle retention of FEC/EB and EC/DEC cells are 62.1% and 36.3%, respectively, much lower than that of the FEC/ETFB cell. Even at a high current of 5 C, the cells with FEC/ETFB still shows satisfied capacity (109 mAh⋅g−1) and cycle retention rate (74.2%) for 200 cycles (Fig. S13). These findings emphasize the exceptional cathode stability under high voltage of 4.5 V in FEC/ETFB electrolyte at RT, implying that the CEI layer formed by the decomposition of this electrolyte is robust enough to protect the structural integrity of LCO cathode. The Li||LCO cell with FEC/ETFB electrolyte not only exhibits excellent performance at RT but also demonstrates exceptional performance at wide temperatures. As shown in the Fig. 4h and Fig. S14, it exhibits a satisfactory reversible capacity of 152.1 mAh·g−1 even at temperature of 60 °C after 200 cycles under 0.5 C, demonstrating excellent retention of 83.5%. Even at high temperatures of up to 70 °C, the capacity of 165 mAh·g−1 and the retention rate of 85.9% are achieved after 100 cycles (Fig. 4i and Fig. S15). For conventional EC/DEC electrolytes under high temperature (60 °C) and voltage, it exhibits extremely unstable CE curves (Fig. 4h) and low cycle retention rates (37%). Despite containing a certain proportion of FEC solvent, FEC/EB electrolyte is also unable to resist the deterioration in 60 °C performance (62% cycle retention after 200 cycles) probably due to EB’s low antioxidant properties. A procedure of charging at RT and discharging at low temperature under 0.1 C current density was used to evaluate the capacity release of Li||LCO cells with FEC/ETFB and other electrolyte at low temperature (from 0 to −60 °C). In Fig. 4f and Fig. 4e, discharge capacity (cut-off voltage is 3 V) of the Li||LCO cell with FEC/ETFB electrolyte shows high retention of their RT discharge capacity at low temperature: 185.6 mAh·g−1 (100%), 183.6 mAh·g−1 (98.9%), 181.3 mAh·g−1 (97.6%), 177.6 mAh·g−1 (95.8%), 167.7 mAh·g−1 (90.3%) and 123.9 mAh·g−1 (66.7%) when cycled at 25 °C, 0 °C, −20 °C, −40 °C, −50 °C and −60 °C, respectively. Representative summative (capacity and retention) curves of Li||LCO cells for above electrolytes at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 4f and Fig. S16. The discharge abilities of electrolytes rank as follows: FEC/ETFB > EC/DEC > FEC/EB. In order to more accurately reflect practical conditions, Li||LCO cells were evaluated (Fig. 4i and Fig. S15) and delivered charge/discharge capacities of 140.8 mAh·g−1 (92.7% retention rate) at 0.2 C under −20 °C after 100 cycles, which also still maintained 91.2 mAh·g−1 capacities at 0.1 C under −40 °C after 100 cycles. To evaluate a comprehensive overview of the wide-temperature property for FEC/ETFB electrolyte, the comparative analysis with recent literatures is listed in Table S2. Noteworthy, our study showcases an exceptional low-temperature specific capacity (−60 °C) and more stable cycle retention at high temperatures (60–70 °C) compared with previous reports. To investigate the improvement mechanism, we characterized the nature of SEI and CEI formed in the electrolyte. 2.5 Analysis of the electrodes-electrolyte interfacial chemistry To better analyze the interfacial chemistry, the morphology and composition of the SEI and CEI on the electrodes after long-term cycles were systematically characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The roughness and thickness of the SEI layers were observed from the top view and cross-section SEM images of Li anode (from Li||LCO cells) in different electrolyte after 200 cycles at RT. A uniform and thin SEI layers of ∼43.4 nm was observed on the Li anode in FEC/ETFB electrolyte during long-term cycles (Fig. 5 c, f). In contrast, a much thicker and coarser SEI layer of ∼86.3 nm was observed for EC/DEC electrolytes (Fig. 5a, d). The SEI resulted from the FEC/EB electrolyte had a thickness in an intermediate range (∼58.4 nm), which is closely associated with the outcomes presented in the preceding electrochemical analysis section. Aiming to gain insights into the ingredient of SEIs in the electrolytes and their implications for anode stability, XPS was employed to further investigate the surface compositions of lithium anodes. The distribution of surface elements (Li, C, O, F and P) are shown in Fig. 5h and Fig. S17. F-atomic percentages for the FEC/ETFB, FEC/EB, and EC/DEC electrolyte are 31.4%, 23.0%, and 12.9%, respectively. On the contrary, the corresponding C-atomic and O-atomic contents are ranked as follows: EC/DEC > FEC/EB > FEC/ETFB, obviously. In Fig. 5i, integral five peaks at 284.8 eV (C–C), 285.8 eV (C–H), 286.9 eV (C–O), 289.1 eV (C = O) and 292.5 eV (C–F) can be observed in XPS C1s curves. In comparison, the components (Li2CO3, ROLi and ROCOLi etc.) produced from the decomposition of organic solvents on the Li metal with the FEC/ETFB electrolyte exhibits a lower scale of C–O and C = O bonds compared with those observed with Li anodes using EC/DEC and FEC/EB electrolytes. In Fig. 5j and 5 k, in-depth X-ray XPS was used to characterize the distribution of LiF across the SEIs derived from the FEC/ETFB electrolytes because LiF plays an decisive role on the electrochemical behavior and deposited Li morphology [7]. The resulting F-atomic content in the SEI is from 31.3% on the surface and increases to no more than 34.2% even after etching 25 nm in depth (Fig. 5j), in which Li–F bond dominates and C–F bond almost disappears after etching at 10 nm (Fig. 5k). Hence, it infers that, on the Li metal anode, robust SEI enriched with LiF forms after cycles, because FEC and ETFB have lower LUMO energy levels and a higher susceptibility to reduction. Consequently, it facilitates the uniform and dense Li deposition, thereby substantially augmenting the long-term cycle for Li||LCO cells. We also characterized the corresponding LCO cathodes in cycled Li/LCO cells using different electrolytes, by SEM, XPS, high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and hard X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), to gain further insights into the evolution of structures on LCO electrodes in various electrolytes and the influences of CEI films derived from them. SEM images show that, even after completing 200 cycles at 3–4.5 V, LCO particles remain smooth surface when using FEC/ETFB electrolyte (Fig. 6 c). In contrast, after cycling in EC/DEC and FEC/EB electrolytes, surface of LCO cathodes experienced varying degrees of cracking (yellow circled border) in its bulk particles (Fig. 6a, b). To directly observe the evolution of LCO microstructure and surface deposition under different electrolyte cycles, HRTEM are used to characterize the cycled LCO cathodes in Fig. 6d–f. After 200 cycles at 3.0–4.5 V, for LCO crystals in all three electrolytes, there exist crystalline domains exhibiting a typical (003) lattice plane, with an interlayer distance of approximately 0.47 nm. Meanwhile, LCO crystals surface are covered with CEI films of different thickness. However, a distinct disordered rock salt region is observed within CEI films when only using EC/DEC electrolyte (Fig. 6d). This is likely caused by the dissolution of Co ions, because of the unstable CEI and the associated catalytic decomposition of the EC/DEC carbonate electrolyte. The surface of the LCO particle undergoes a transformation from original layered structure to a rock-salt structure, thereby potentially impeding interfacial charge transfer as evidenced by the EIS (Fig. S18a). In contrast, the cycled LCO cathode and FEC/ETFB electrolyte (Fig. 6d, f) without obvious phase transition region, implying the surface structural phase transition is inhibited by CEI films. Although the same phenomenon is also observed in FEC/EB electrolyte, the CEI (∼9–10 nm) formed is thicker than the former (∼3–5 nm), obviously. The XPS spectra in Fig. 6h and Fig. S18b were utilized for characterizing the components of CEI films, and the results of element distribution exhibited similarities to those observed in the anode section. Notably, the pivotal F-atomic content ranks as FEC/ETFB (35.6%) > FEC/EB (28.9%) > EC/EDC (9.8%). Moreover, when using FEC/ETFB electrolyte, the surface content of Li-F species (at 685.5 eV) far exceeds the C-F species (at 688.6 eV) (Fig. 6i), suggesting that the main component of the SEI is inorganic LiF. Therefore, it can be inferred that recycled LCO in FEC/ETFB electrolyte forms a strong, thin and LiF-rich CEI film. Further, XRD and hard XAS were used to characterize the integrity of the layered structure for cycled LCO cathodes under above CEI films protection. As displayed in Fig. S18c, XRD patterns of cycled LCO cathodes indicate that the (003) peak, characteristic of the layered cathode structure, is largely retained after cycling. However, the (003) peak of uncycled LCO shifts from 18.92° to 18.71° in the EC/DEC cell after 200 cycles, indicating a significant phase transition of LCO caused by Co dissolution. The (003) peaks for cycled LCO in FEC/ETFB and EFC/EB only shift to 18.89° and 18.87°, respectively, inferring the Co ion dissolution is greatly inhibited with the Li-rich CEI. In Fig. 6j, hard XAS spectra of pristine and cycled LCO are presented for characterizing the valence change of Co ions. The initial appearance of the Co3+ peak at a binding energy of ∼7728 eV is consistent with the well-structured LCO crystals [14,67]. However, after 200 cycles, there is a shift in photon energy to ∼7729 eV for the Co peaks for LCO in EC/DEC electrolyte. This shift indicates an irreversible oxidation of Co4+ and the loss of lattice oxygen. The behavior exhibited by the Co peaks for LCO in FEC/EFTB electrolyte showed negligible variations. The wavelet transforms (WT) of the k2-weighted hard XAS signal in Fig. 6k and Fig. S19 indicate that the Co-O peak of cycled LCO in FEC/ETFB electrolyte exhibits a slight wavenumber shift compared to those in FEC/EB and EC/DEC electrolytes, confirming successful inhibition of oxygen lattice loss on the LCO cathode. The results clearly illustrate that the enhancement of LiF-rich CEI films produced by FEC/ETFB electrolyte can significantly maintain the integrity of LCO structure during electrochemical cycling, and then increase the cycling stability of LCO at high voltages. 2.6 Performance of 4.5 V Li||LCO pouch cell with FEC/ETFB electrolyte Especially, to test the actual performance of electrolyte in full cells, we chose FEC/ETFB electrolyte, LCO as the cathode, commercial Cu-Li composite foil as the anode to assemble pouch cells (∼0.2 Ah). Fig. 7 a displays a digital photograph that the pouch cell lights the blue LED. The rate capability and charge–discharge curves of pouch cells is shown in Fig. 7b, c. Corresponding capacities at the current density of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2 and 4 C are 208, 203, 198, 183, 161 and 141 mAh, respectively. Excellent cycling performance was demonstrated in Fig. 6e and Fig. 6f with a high capacity of ∼189 mAh (93.5% capacity retention) at 0.2 C after 100 cycles. Meanwhile, as shown in Fig. 6f, high capacity was derived up to 201, 195, 178, 159 and 118 mAh when the cell was discharged at 0 °C, −20 °C, −40 °C, −50 °C and −60 °C, respectively. Remarkably, even at an elevated temperature of 70 °C, the cell still released a high capacity of 210 mAh. The performance of the pouch cell proves that the FEC/ETFB electrolyte has great potential for the applications in all-climate LMBs. 3 Conclusions A novel nonflammable fluorinated electrolyte is designed by incorporating partially-fluorinated ester ETFB as a cosolvent and employing fluorine-functional groups to adjust the ion pairs and solvation structures. Experimental results indicate that the ETFB solvent effectively modulates the coordination ability of the fluorinated solvent through the interactions with Li+ and PF6 −, thereby enhancing oxidation stability and reducing the energy barrier for Li+ de/solvation. This intermolecular interaction significantly improves the performance of 4.5 V Li||LCO cells, enabling their operation within a wide temperature range (from −60 °C to 70 °C) and at high voltages (4.5 V). Specifically, the pouch cell employing electrolytes with ETFB shows excellent cycling stability and wide temperature discharge properties. This work unequivocally demonstrates the beneficial impact of ETFB co-solvent on the cyclic stability of high voltage (4.5 V) Li||LCO cells under wide temperature, while providing a feasible approach to high safety and wide temperature adaptability LMBs. Last but not least, this work can also inspire the in-depth exploration of more local fluorinated solvents with different fluorinated substitution sites for wide temperature LMBs electrolyte design. coredata.dc:description: Efficient, safe, and reliable energy output from high-energy–density lithium metal batteries (LMBs) at all climates is crucial for portable electronic devices operating in complex environments. The performance of corresponding cathodes and lithium (Li) metal anodes, however, faces significant challenges under such demanding conditions. Herein, a nonflammable electrolyte for high-voltage Li||LCO cells has been designed, including partially-fluorinated ethyl 4,4,4-trifluorobutyrate (ETFB) as the key solvent, guided by theoretical calculations. With this ETFB-based electrolyte, Li||LCO cells exhibit enhanced reversible capacities and superior capacity retention at an elevated charge voltage of 4.5 V and a wide operating temperature range spanning from −60 °C to 70 °C. The cells achieve 67.1% discharge capacity at −60 °C, relative to room temperature capacity, and 85.9% 100th-cycle retention at 70 °C. The outstanding properties are attributed to the LiF-rich interphases formed in the ETFB-based electrolyte with a fine-tuned solvation structure, in which the coordination environment in the vicinity of Li+ cations and the distance between anion and solvents are subtly adjusted by introducing ETFB. This solvation structure has been mutually elucidated through joint spectra characterizations and atomistic simulations. This work presents a new strategy for the design of electrolytes to achieve all-climate reliable and safe application of LMBs.
